topic.shortdesc: Restore data and provide options to include or exclude buckets and data from the restore process.

section.title: Description
section.p: Backups are taken in to protect against data loss or corruption. When these situations happen, you want to be able to restore backed up data back to your cluster. Use the restore command, which restores data and provides options to include or exclude buckets and data from the restore process.

The restore command allows you also to specify which parts of a backup you want to restore by providing restore options similar to the ones in the create command. Using these options allows you to specify which buckets should be restored and whether or not to restore the bucket configuration, views, indexes, full-text indexes or data during the restore process.

section.title: Options
section.p:
The following are the command options:
restore options
Option Description
--dir /[directory name] Path of the backup archive. REQUIRED
--name REPOSITORY-NAME Name of the backup respositor to be restored. REQUIRED
--host HOSTNAME Name of the host where the backup is to be restored. REQUIRED
--username USERNAME Login of the administrator who is restoring the backup. REQUIRED
--password PASSWORD Password of the administrator who is restoring the backup. REQUIRED
--start [backup number] Number of the first backup from which to restore.
--end [backup number] Number of the last backup through which to restore.
--include-buckets [BUCKET-NAMES] A comma separated list of buckets to back up. Only buckets in this list are backed up.
--exclude-buckets [BUCKET-NAMES] A comma separated list of buckets to exclude from backups. All buckets except for the ones specified will be backed up.
--disable-bucket-config Disables backing up the bucket config information
--disable-views Disables backing up view definitions
--disable-gsi-indexes Disables backing up GSI index definitions
--disable-ft-indexes Disables backing up Full Text index definitions
--disable-data Disables backing up cluster data
--force-updates By default conflict resolution is used so that backup data does not overwrite more recent data. Specify this option to force backup data to overwrite newer data.
--threads The amount of parallelism used during backup. (Default is 1).
--no-progress-bar Disables printing of the progress bar.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Restores all backups in the backup repository travel: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password

In the examples below, data was backed up in the archive /data/couchbase/backups and backup repository travel. This backup repository contains four backups with stamps 2016-01-19T15:41:25.448936431-08:00, 2016-01-20T15:32:15.124936651-08:00, 2016-01-21T15:39:31.828976983-08:00, and 2016-01-22T15:42:41.383468246-08:00.

Restores the two most recent backups in the backup repository travel: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --start 2016-01-21T15:39:31.828976983-08:00

Does not restore the first and last backups in the backup repository travel: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --start 2016-01-20T15:32:15.124936651-08:00 \ --end 2016-01-21T15:39:31.828976983-08:00

Only restores the last backup in the backup repository travel: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --start 2016-01-22T15:42:41.383468246-08:00 \ --end 2016-01-22T15:42:41.383468246-08:00

Restores all backups in the backup repository travel, but restores only the travel-sample bucket and uses 4 threads for parallelism: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --include-buckets travel-sample --threads 4

Restores all backups in the sample backup repository travel, but skips restoring data: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --disable-data

Restores all backups in the sample backup repository travel, but restores only the views in the travel-sample bucket: ./backup restore --dir /data/couchbase/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --include-buckets travel-sample \ --disable-bucket-config --disable-gsi-indexes --disable--ft-indexes --disable-data
